questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
Upon further questioning including review of systems, it was discovered that the patient owns a cat and has been scratched twice in the last 6 months. Lab work serology demonstrated very high titers of Bartonella IgG (<1:256). Testing for toxoplasma gondii IgM, RPR, FTA-ABS and quantiferon gold was negative.

Based on the history and OCT, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Neuroretinitis refers to the inflammation of the optic nerve head. Though associated with a macular star, this sign may take 1-2 weeks to develop, and therefore may not be present in early stages of neuroretinitis. In neuroretinitis, inflammation of the optic disc occurs first with exudative leakage into the retina. The lipid-rich component of this exudate deposits into the peripapillary outer plexiform layer, which may not be seen at presentation.

The most common cause of infectious neuroretinitis is from the bacteria Bartonella henselae which can be present on a cat’s claws or teeth (otherwise known as Cat Scratch Disease). Ischemic optic neuropathy is less likely as the patient does not endorse any vascular risk factors and vision is relatively preserved. Similarly, papilledema would often present with other associated symptoms such as headache, pulsatile tinnitus, and a lack of inflammatory intraocular changes (eg. vitreous cells). Optic neuritis would fit this patient demographic, but the absence of pain, relatively preserved visual function, absence of an RAPD tends away from this diagnosis.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Which of the following is a potential complication of infectious neuroretinitis?

answers.explanation: It has been suggested that antibiotics and steroids may shorten the recovery period of infectious neuroretinitis; however, many cases have been self-limiting in otherwise healthy individuals; therefore, strong statistical conclusions cannot be made. As exudative fluid penetrates the retina, it passes through the external limiting membrane and accumulates in the subretinal space, giving rise to a detachment in some cases. Central retinal vein occlusion and choroidal neovascularization are not complications of Neuroretinitis, but may mimic it and complicate the diagnosis. Though drusen are also lipid-rich, they are located below the retina.
